# Project Summary Description

## Overview
The project aims to address environmental and social challenges by implementing the distribution of Improved Cook Stoves (ICS) in Ulmera, Timor-Leste. Through the adoption of these technologies, the project seeks to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by promoting the efficient use of firewood, thereby decreasing the demand for firewood and mitigating GHG emissions.

## Technologies/Measures
The project focuses on the distribution of Improved Cook Stoves to households in Ulmera. These stoves are designed to improve the efficiency of cooking processes, leading to reduced fuel consumption and lower emissions. To ensure the effectiveness of the project, annual and biennial surveys will be conducted to monitor stove usage. Local leaders play a crucial role in selecting beneficiaries based on predefined criteria, enhancing community engagement and ownership.

## Location
The project is situated in Timor-Leste, specifically in various municipalities within the country. By targeting households in Ulmera, the project aims to directly impact the local community and environment.

## GHG Emission Reductions
By encouraging the use of Improved Cook Stoves, the project anticipates a reduction in GHG emissions. The efficient combustion of firewood in these stoves minimizes waste and leads to lower emissions compared to traditional cooking methods. Through the installation of these stoves, the project aims to achieve tangible reductions in carbon dioxide emissions.

## Scenario Prior to Project
Before the implementation of the project, previous initiatives introducing Improved Cook Stoves faced challenges that hindered their success. Issues such as high upfront costs, inadequate resources, poor technology selection, and community involvement limitations prevented these programs from progressing beyond the pilot stage. The current project aims to overcome these challenges through strategic planning and community engagement.

## Estimates
Over the ten-year crediting period, the project targets an annual average reduction/removal of approximately 507,463 metric tons of CO2 equivalent (tCO2e). This translates to a total reduction/removal of 5,074,630 tCO2e, demonstrating the significant impact the project aims to achieve in mitigating GHG emissions and promoting sustainable practices.

By implementing the distribution of Improved Cook Stoves and engaging with local communities, the project seeks to create a positive environmental and social impact in Ulmera, Timor-Leste, contributing to global efforts towards climate change mitigation.
